title: Daniel's Prayer and Prophecy
shortSummary: Daniel chapter 9 records the prophet Daniel’s earnest prayer of confession and intercession for Israel’s restoration, followed by the angel Gabriel’s revelation of the prophetic timeline of seventy weeks concerning the coming Messiah and the future of Jerusalem. This chapter highlights the themes of repentance, divine mercy, and God’s sovereign plan for redemption.
timeline: c. 538 BC - Early Persian period under King Darius, during the Jewish exile and beginning of restoration

keyCharacters.name: Daniel
keyCharacters.description: A prophet and leader among the Jewish exiles who prays fervently for his people and receives divine revelation.

keyCharacters.name: Gabriel
keyCharacters.description: An angelic messenger who appears to Daniel to explain the meaning of the seventy weeks prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Darius the son of Ahasuerus
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king reigning over the Chaldean realm at the time of Daniel’s prayer.

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet whose writings Daniel references regarding the seventy years of Jerusalem’s desolation.

definitions.definition: A prophetic period symbolizing seventy sets of seven years, used to outline God’s plan for Israel’s redemption and the coming of the Messiah.
The anointed one promised by God, fulfilled in Jesus Christ, who brings salvation and establishes everlasting righteousness.
A religious offering or sacrifice presented to God, often referring to temple sacrifices.
Acknowledgment and repentance of sins before God, seeking His mercy and forgiveness.

outline.heading: Daniel’s Prayer of Confession and Supplication
outline.description: Daniel acknowledges the fulfillment of Jeremiah’s prophecy about seventy years of desolation and prays earnestly, confessing Israel’s sins and pleading for God’s mercy and restoration of Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Gabriel’s Arrival and Introduction
outline.description: While Daniel is praying, the angel Gabriel appears swiftly to give him understanding and insight into the vision and prophetic message concerning Israel’s future.

outline.heading: The Prophecy of Seventy Weeks
outline.description: Gabriel reveals the timeline of seventy weeks decreed for Israel and Jerusalem, outlining the coming of the Messiah, the cutting off of the Messiah, the destruction of the city, and the final consummation of God’s redemptive plan.

application: Approach God with humility and repentance, confessing personal and corporate sins as Daniel did, trusting in His mercy.
Persist in prayer and supplication, seeking God’s guidance and understanding in times of uncertainty or trial.
Trust in God’s sovereign plan for redemption, even when circumstances seem bleak, knowing He will fulfill His promises.
Recognize the importance of Jesus Christ as the Messiah who brings reconciliation and everlasting righteousness.

keyVerses.text: And I set my face unto the Lord God, to seek by prayer and supplications, with fasting, and sackcloth, and ashes:
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates Daniel’s earnest and humble approach to God in prayer, modeling sincere repentance and devotion.

keyVerses.text: Seventy weeks are determined upon thy people and upon thy holy city, to finish the transgression, and to make an end of sins, and to make reconciliation for iniquity, and to bring in everlasting righteousness, and to seal up the vision and prophecy, and to anoint the most Holy.
keyVerses.significance: This verse outlines the comprehensive purpose of God’s prophetic timeline, culminating in the Messiah’s work of redemption.

keyVerses.text: And after threescore and two weeks shall Messiah be cut off, but not for himself: and the people of the prince that shall come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary; and the end thereof shall be with a flood, and unto the end of the war desolations are determined.
keyVerses.significance: Foretells the Messiah’s sacrificial death and the subsequent destruction of Jerusalem, highlighting God’s sovereign control over history.

keyVerses.text: And he shall confirm the covenant with many for one week: and in the midst of the week he shall cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease, and for the overspreading of abominations he shall make it desolate, even until the consummation, and that determined shall be poured upon the desolate.
keyVerses.significance: Describes the final week of the prophecy, emphasizing the cessation of temple sacrifices and the coming desolation, pointing to ultimate judgment and restoration.
